newsitem.title: UK: British watchdog unhinged over plastic portal.
newsitem.headline: British watchdog unhinged over plastic portal.

text.p: A brown plastic front door at the centre of a two-year, 80,000 pounds ($132,000) legal battle will be allowed to remain at a house in a northern English village.
Britain's state-funded architectural watchdog body, English Heritage, argued that the polymer portal was unsuitable in a conservation area and could set a dangerous precedent.

But its arguments as framed were rejected by Britain's High Court on Tuesday and the door on the modest three-storey house in the village of Wirksworth, 200 miles (320 kms) north of London, will not be unhinged.
"We are very disappointed but are glad that the issue has had a public airing," an English Heritage spokeswoman said on Wednesday. "We hope that the ruling doesn't set a precedent."

The door's owner, Patricia Harman, 53, said English Heritage had so far spent 80,000 pounds -- about twice the value of her home -- trying to have her mock-Georgian door in simulated mahogany removed.
"Stand on the other side of the street and you would not take a blind bit of notice of it," she told reporters after the ruling. "It was two years after I put it in before anyone noticed."

English Heritage argued that the door threatened the architectural fabric of the village and has not yet given up the fight to have it replaced with a wooden variety. "We are taking legal advice about a possible appeal," its spokesman said. ($1=.6072 Pound)
